docTitle.titlePart:
A recombinant immunotoxin containing a disulfide-stabilized
Fv fragment

byline.docAuthor: ULRICH BRINKMANN, YORAM REITER, SUN-HEE JUNG, BYUNGKOOK LEE, AND IRA PASTAN

byline.affiliation: Laboratory of Molecular Biology, Division of Cancer Biology, Diagnosis, and Centers, National Cancer Institute, National Institutes of Health,

front.div:
ABSTRACT B3(dsFv)-PE38KDEL is a recombinant im-
munotoxin composed of the Fv region of monoclonal antibody
B3 connected to a truncated form of Pseudomonas exotoxin
(PE38KDEL), in which the unstabl Fv heterodimer (composed
of heavy-and ight-chain variable regions) is held together and
stabilized by a dbsulfde bond [termed disulfide-stabilized Fv
(dsFv)]. A computer modeled structure of the B3(Fv), made by
mutating and energy miniming the amino acid sequence and
structure of McPC603, enabled us to identify positions in
conserved framework regions that "hypothetically" could be
used for disulflde stabilization without changing the structure
or affing antigen biding. This predon was evaluated
experimentally by constucting a disulfidelinked two-chain
dsFv-immunotoxin that was produced in Eschenchia col. The
activity and specificity of this immunotoxin was indistinguish-
able from its single-chain Fv (scFv) counterpart, indicating
that, as in B3(scFv), the structure of the binding reion is
retained in B3(dsFv). Because we introduced the stabilizing
disulfide bond in between two framework residues in a position
that is conserved in most Fv molecules, this method of lnkage
between the heavy-and light-chain variable regions should be
generaiy applicable to construct immunotoxins and dsFv mol-
ecules using other antibodies. Furthermore, the finding that
B3(dsFv) was much more stable at 370C in human plasma than
B3(scFv) indicates that dsFvs are possibly more versatile for
therapeutic application than scFvs.
